ground_truth: He is young and vigorous and swivels on the ground as though to strike back, but Nehru lunges toward him and a lathi is brought smashing across the side of Nehru's head. He feels the side of his head, the blood soaking his hand, and struggles to his feet, facing the policeman who has struck him. The Viceroy ponders it favorably, while the senior police officer is brought up by the chill directness of it. He looks at Irwin and the principal secretary for a moment in uncertainty. As he turns to leave, Irwin speaks almost offhandedly, and the senior police officer stares at him. Barbed wire stretches on either side of the stockade-like entrance, and above the gate we see the sign DHARASANA SALT WORKS. Before it, six British police officers and two Indian police officers command a large troop of Indian policemen. They face their opposition, unmoving, tense. The camera pans from them, across a sloping dip in the ground, to a huge group of volunteers lining up to face the police as tautly as the police face them. Walker is off to one side, climbing to stand in the back of Collin's car, watching, looking tensely from one group to the other, almost terrified by what seems about to happen. Collins leans against the back of the car near him, watching with an equally appalled expectancy, and there are two other reporters near them. From Walker's point of view, we see Mirabehn and some Indian women quietly placing stretchers and tables of bandages near a group of tents where the volunteers have been housed. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance, and the air itself seems breathless with tension. He has approached the chief police officer and stops before him politely. He turns and starts down the dip toward the gate and the waiting lathis of the police. A series of shots shows Azad leading the first row of volunteers down and up the dip as we intercut Walker, frozen, watching the inevitable onslaught, with the British police commanding officer ready to give the first order. He speaks it, trying only half successfully to keep the emotion from his voice. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk, looking still in some kind of shock, staring at Gandhi, and faces Gandhi stiffly. The whirr of a camera, and a swift cut to a wide screen, but slightly under-cranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, are waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails, with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat, all of them smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: He is youthful and robust and rotates on the earth as though to retaliate, but Nehru dashes toward him and a lathi is brought crashing across the side of Nehru's head. He senses the side of his skull, the blood saturating his hand, and struggles to his feet, confronting the policeman who has struck him. The Viceroy considers it favorably, while the senior police officer is brought up by the chill directness of it. He glances at Irwin and the principal secretary for a moment in doubt. As he turns to depart, Irwin speaks almost casually, and the senior police officer gazes at him. Barbed wire extends on either flank of the stockade-like entrance, and above the gate we observe the sign DHARASANA SALT WORKS. Before it, six British police officers and two Indian police officers command a large squad of Indian policemen. They confront their opposition, unmoving, strained. The camera pans from them, across a sloping depression in the earth, to a vast group of volunteers lining up to face the police as tightly as the police face them. Walker is off to one flank, climbing to stand in the rear of Collin's car, observing, looking tensely from one group to the other, almost frightened by what seems about to transpire. Collins leans against the rear of the automobile near him, observing with an equally appalled expectation, and there are two other journalists near them. From Walker's perspective, we observe Mirabehn and some Indian women quietly placing stretchers and tables of bandages near a group of tents where the volunteers have been accommodated. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance, and the atmosphere itself seems breathless with strain. He has approached the chief police officer and halts before him respectfully. He turns and starts down the depression toward the gate and the waiting lathis of the police. A series of shots shows Azad leading the first row of volunteers down and up the depression as we intercut Walker, frozen, watching the inevitable assault, with the British police commanding officer prepared to give the first command. He speaks it, trying only half successfully to keep the emotion from his voice. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk, looking still in some kind of daze, staring at Gandhi, and faces Gandhi rigidly. The whirr of a camera, and a swift transition to a wide screen, but slightly under-cranked with the poor cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, are waving farewell from the boat deck of their vessel as it sails, with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat, all of them smiling at the camera like travelers everywhere.

The side of his head is felt by him, the blood soaking his hand, and he struggles to his feet, facing the policeman who has struck him. The camera is panned by us from them, across a sloping dip in the ground, to a huge group of volunteers lining up to face the police as tautly as the police face them. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance, and the air itself seems breathless with tension. The chief police officer is approached by him and he stops before him politely. The dip is turned and started down by him toward the gate and the waiting lathis of the police. A series of shots shows Azad leading the first row of volunteers down and up the dip as we intercut Walker, frozen, watching the inevitable onslaught, with the British police commanding officer ready to give the first order. It is spoken by him, trying only half successfully to keep the emotion from his voice. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk, looking still in some kind of shock, stares at Gandhi, and faces Gandhi stiffly. The whirr of a camera, and a swift cut to a wide screen, but it is slightly under-cranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, wave goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails, with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat, all of them smile at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: He is young and vigorous, swiveling on the ground as if to strike back, but Nehru lunges at him, and a lathi smashes across Nehru's head. He feels the blood soaking his hand and struggles to his feet, facing the policeman who struck him. The Viceroy ponders favorably, while the senior police officer is taken aback by its directness. He looks at Irwin and the principal secretary uncertainly. As he turns to leave, Irwin speaks offhandedly, and the officer stares at him. Barbed wire stretches on either side of the stockade-like entrance, with the sign DHARASANA SALT WORKS above the gate. Six British and two Indian police officers command a large troop of Indian policemen, facing their opposition tensely. The camera pans to a large group of volunteers lining up to face the police. Walker stands in the back of Collin's car, watching tensely, almost terrified by the impending events. Collins leans against the car, watching with appalled expectancy, alongside two other reporters. From Walker's view, Mirabehn and Indian women place stretchers and bandages near tents housing volunteers. Walker turns back to the opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance, the air tense. He approaches the chief police officer, then starts toward the gate and the waiting lathis. Azad leads the first row of volunteers down and up the dip as Walker watches the inevitable onslaught, with the British commanding officer ready to give the order, trying to keep emotion from his voice. Irwin, in shadows behind his desk, looks shocked, staring stiffly at Gandhi. A camera whirrs, cutting to a wide screen with old newsreel music. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Desai wave goodbye from their ship's deck as it sails, with Mirabehn holding a goat's tether, all smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: He is young and vigorous, ready to strike back, but Nehru lunges, and a lathi hits Nehru's head. He feels blood on his hand and faces the policeman. The Viceroy considers it favorably, while the senior officer is taken aback. As he leaves, Irwin speaks offhandedly, and the officer stares. Barbed wire flanks the entrance to DHARASANA SALT WORKS, guarded by British and Indian officers facing tense opposition. The camera pans to volunteers lining up. Walker stands in Collin's car, watching tensely. Collins and other reporters share his apprehension. Mirabehn and Indian women prepare stretchers and bandages near tents. Walker turns to the opposing groups, tension in the air. He approaches the chief officer, then heads toward the gate and police lathis. Azad leads volunteers down the dip as Walker watches, and the British officer gives the order. Irwin, in shock, faces Gandhi. A camera whirrs, cutting to a newsreel of Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Desai waving goodbye from a ship, with Mirabehn holding a goat, all smiling.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: He is a young and vigorous man, full of energy and vitality, and he swivels on the ground as if preparing to strike back. However, Nehru lunges toward him with determination, and suddenly, a lathi is brought down with force, smashing across the side of Nehru's head. He instinctively reaches up to feel the side of his head, and his hand comes away soaked with blood. Despite the pain, he struggles to his feet, facing the policeman who has struck him with a defiant gaze. Meanwhile, the Viceroy ponders the situation favorably, while the senior police officer is taken aback by the chill directness of the event. He glances at Irwin and the principal secretary, momentarily uncertain about what to do next. As he turns to leave, Irwin speaks almost offhandedly, and the senior police officer stares at him, trying to comprehend the implications. Barbed wire stretches ominously on either side of the stockade-like entrance, and above the gate, the sign reads DHARASANA SALT WORKS. In front of it, six British police officers and two Indian police officers command a large troop of Indian policemen. They stand facing their opposition, unmoving and tense, like statues ready for action. The camera pans slowly from them, across a sloping dip in the ground, to a massive group of volunteers lining up to face the police with the same tautness as the police face them. Off to one side, Walker is climbing to stand in the back of Collin's car, watching the scene unfold with tense anticipation, almost terrified by the potential for violence that seems imminent. Collins leans against the back of the car near him, watching with an equally appalled expectancy, and there are two other reporters standing nearby, observing the unfolding drama. From Walker's point of view, we see Mirabehn and some Indian women quietly placing stretchers and tables of bandages near a group of tents where the volunteers have been housed, preparing for the inevitable. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance, and the air itself seems to hold its breath, thick with tension. He approaches the chief police officer and stops before him politely, acknowledging the gravity of the moment. He then turns and starts down the dip toward the gate, where the waiting lathis of the police are poised for action. A series of shots captures Azad leading the first row of volunteers down and up the dip, as we intercut with Walker, frozen in place, watching the inevitable onslaught unfold. The British police commanding officer stands ready to give the first order, speaking it with an effort to keep the emotion from his voice, though not entirely succeeding. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk, still in some kind of shock, staring at Gandhi with a stiff demeanor. The whirr of a camera is heard, followed by a swift cut to a wide screen, slightly under-cranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, are seen waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails away, with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat. All of them are smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere, capturing a moment of departure and hope.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
In the unfolding scene, we encounter a man who is youthful and full of vigor, brimming with energy and vitality that cannot be easily contained. He moves with agility, swiveling on the ground with an air of readiness as though he is about to launch a retaliatory strike. Despite this, Nehru, driven by sheer determination and resolve, lunges toward the young man. In an abrupt and forceful motion, a lathi is brought crashing down with unrelenting force, striking Nehru across the side of his head. Instinctively, he reaches up to feel where the blow landed, and his fingers come away covered in blood, crimson and fresh. Despite experiencing significant pain, he manages to struggle to his feet, confronting the policeman who has just struck him, meeting his gaze with defiance and courage. Concurrently, the Viceroy regards the situation with a favorable disposition, while the senior police officer displays a reaction of shock, bewildered by the cold directness of the event unfolding before him. He glances nervously at Irwin and the principal secretary, momentarily at a loss for his next course of action. As he turns to depart, Irwin speaks in an almost casual manner, and the senior police officer fixes him with a stare, attempting to grasp the full implications of the words spoken. 

Stretching ominously on either side of the stockade-like entrance is barbed wire, casting a foreboding presence, while above the gate a sign reads "DHARASANA SALT WORKS" in stark lettering. Positioned in front of this entrance, six British police officers and two Indian police officers maintain command over a substantial troop of Indian policemen. They stand facing their opposition, frozen and tense in position, resembling statues poised and ready for action. The camera's lens pans deliberately and slowly away from them, spanning across a sloping dip in the ground, to capture a massive congregation of volunteers. These volunteers are lining up with determination, mirroring the tautness with which the police confront them. Off to one side of the scene, Walker is seen cautiously climbing to take a position in the back of Collin's car, intently observing the scene as it unfolds with a mix of tense anticipation and near-terror at the potential for imminent violence. Collins stands leaning against the back of the car near Walker, equally engrossed with an appalled expectancy, while two other reporters are positioned nearby, keenly observing the dramatic unfolding of events.

From Walker's vantage point, we observe Mirabehn and a group of Indian women moving quietly and efficiently, placing stretchers and tables laden with bandages in strategic locations near a cluster of tents designated for housing the volunteers, preparing with calm resolve for what seems unavoidable. Walker then shifts his focus back to the two opposing groups stationed at the Salt Works entrance, where the atmosphere feels thick, as if the very air is holding its breath in anticipation. He approaches the chief police officer in a manner that is both polite and respectful, acknowledging the gravity of the moment. He then pivots and begins to proceed down the dip towards the gate, where the police stand with lathis at the ready, poised for action. 

A succession of shots showcases Azad gracefully leading the first row of volunteers as they traverse the dip's descent and ascent, intercutting these images with views of Walker, who remains still, frozen in place as he watches the unavoidable onslaught about to take place. The commanding officer of the British police stands prepared to issue the initial order, speaking the command with a strained attempt to suppress the emotion in his voice, though his success in doing so is only partial. Irwin is seen ensconced in shadow behind his desk, still experiencing some degree of shock, his gaze fixed on Gandhi with an expression that is rigid. The sound of a camera whirring is heard, transitioning swiftly to a wide-screen view that is slightly under-cranked, accompanied by the imperfect editing and predictable soundtrack of outdated newsreels. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, are depicted waving farewell from the boat deck of their departing ship, with Mirabehn holding onto the tether of a goat. Each is smiling at the camera, embodying the spirit of voyagers heading into the unknown, capturing a moment imbued with hope and the promise of new beginnings.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He is young and full of energy, and as he moves swiftly on the ground, it seems as though he is preparing to retaliate. In that moment, Nehru makes a sudden forward movement toward him, but before he can act, a lathi is swung with force, crashing into the side of Nehru's head. Nehru instinctively reaches up to touch the side of his head, feeling the warm blood that now covers his hand. Despite the pain and disorientation, he struggles to his feet, determined to face the policeman who has just struck him. Meanwhile, the Viceroy observes the situation with a sense of approval, while the senior police officer is momentarily taken aback by the cold, direct nature of the event. He glances at Irwin and the principal secretary, his expression uncertain as he processes what has just occurred. As he begins to turn away, Irwin speaks in a manner that seems almost casual, prompting the senior police officer to fix his gaze on him, trying to comprehend the implications. Barbed wire stretches out on either side of the entrance, which resembles a stockade, and above the gate, the sign reads DHARASANA SALT WORKS. Positioned before it are six British police officers and two Indian police officers, who are in command of a large contingent of Indian policemen. They stand firm, facing their opposition with a tense stillness. The camera slowly moves from their position, across a gentle slope in the ground, to reveal a massive group of volunteers who are lining up with equal tension to confront the police. Off to one side, Walker climbs up to stand in the back of Collin's car, his eyes darting nervously between the two groups, almost paralyzed by the anticipation of what seems inevitable. Collins leans against the back of the car nearby, sharing Walker's sense of dreadful expectation, while two other reporters stand close by, observing the scene. From Walker's vantage point, we see Mirabehn and several Indian women quietly setting up stretchers and arranging tables with bandages near a cluster of tents where the volunteers have been staying. Walker shifts his focus back to the two opposing groups at the entrance of the Salt Works, where the atmosphere is thick with tension, as if the air itself is holding its breath. He approaches the chief police officer and stops in front of him with a polite demeanor. Then, he turns and begins to make his way down the slope toward the gate, where the police stand ready with their lathis. A sequence of shots captures Azad leading the first row of volunteers as they descend and then ascend the slope, intercut with images of Walker, frozen in place, watching the impending clash, and the British police commanding officer, who is poised to issue the first command. He speaks the order, his voice betraying a hint of emotion despite his efforts to remain composed. In a different setting, Irwin sits in the shadows behind his desk, still appearing somewhat in shock, as he stares stiffly at Gandhi. The sound of a camera whirring is followed by a quick cut to a wide screen, slightly under-cranked, with the rough editing and predictable music typical of old newsreels. On the screen, Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, are seen waving goodbye from the deck of their ship as it departs, with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat. They all smile at the camera, embodying the spirit of travelers everywhere.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The young man, full of vigor, swivels on the ground as if to retaliate, but Nehru lunges toward him and is struck on the head by a lathi. Feeling the blood on his hand, Nehru struggles to his feet to face the policeman who hit him. Meanwhile, the Viceroy considers the situation favorably, while the senior police officer, caught off guard by the directness of the event, exchanges uncertain glances with Irwin and the principal secretary. As he turns to leave, Irwin speaks casually, prompting a stare from the senior officer. Barbed wire flanks the stockade-like entrance to the DHARASANA SALT WORKS, where six British and two Indian police officers command a large troop of Indian policemen, facing their opposition with tense stillness. The camera pans to a large group of volunteers lining up to confront the police with equal tension. Walker, standing in the back of Collin's car, watches anxiously, while Collins and two other reporters share his apprehension. Nearby, Mirabehn and some Indian women quietly prepare stretchers and bandages near the volunteers' tents. Walker turns back to the tense standoff at the Salt Works entrance. He approaches the chief police officer, then moves toward the gate and the waiting lathis. Azad leads the first row of volunteers down and up the dip, as Walker watches the impending clash, and the British commanding officer prepares to give the first order, his voice barely concealing his emotion. Irwin, in shadows behind his desk, appears shocked as he faces Gandhi stiffly. A camera whirrs, cutting to a slightly under-cranked newsreel showing Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Desai waving goodbye from a ship's deck, with Mirabehn holding a goat's tether, all smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He is young and vigorous and swivels on the ground as though to strike back, but Nehru, who was a prominent leader in India's struggle for independence, lunges toward him and a lathi, a traditional Indian baton used by police forces, is brought smashing across the side of Nehru's head. He feels the side of his head, the blood soaking his hand, and struggles to his feet, facing the policeman who has struck him. The Viceroy, the British official representing the crown in India, ponders it favorably, while the senior police officer is brought up by the chill directness of it. He looks at Irwin, known formally as Lord Irwin who was the Viceroy of India from 1926 to 1931, and the principal secretary for a moment in uncertainty. As he turns to leave, Irwin speaks almost offhandedly, and the senior police officer stares at him. Barbed wire stretches on either side of the stockade-like entrance, and above the gate we see the sign DHARASANA SALT WORKS, a site of protest during the Non-Cooperation Movement. Before it, six British police officers and two Indian police officers command a large troop of Indian policemen. They face their opposition, unmoving, tense. The camera pans from them, across a sloping dip in the ground, to a huge group of volunteers lining up to face the police as tautly as the police face them. Walker, a journalist covering the events for an international audience, is off to one side, climbing to stand in the back of Collin's car, watching, looking tensely from one group to the other, almost terrified by what seems about to happen. Collins leans against the back of the car near him, watching with an equally appalled expectancy, and there are two other reporters near them. From Walker's point of view, we see Mirabehn, a British woman and close associate of Gandhi, and some Indian women quietly placing stretchers and tables of bandages near a group of tents where the volunteers have been housed. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance, and the air itself seems breathless with tension. He has approached the chief police officer and stops before him politely. He turns and starts down the dip toward the gate and the waiting lathis of the police. A series of shots shows Azad, a key figure in the Indian independence movement, leading the first row of volunteers down and up the dip as we intercut Walker, frozen, watching the inevitable onslaught, with the British police commanding officer ready to give the first order. He speaks it, trying only half successfully to keep the emotion from his voice. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk, looking still in some kind of shock, staring at Gandhi, the leader of the Indian independence movement known for his philosophy of nonviolent resistance, and faces Gandhi stiffly. The whirr of a camera, and a swift cut to a wide screen, but slightly under-cranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Gandhi's secretary, Desai, are waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails, with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat, all of them smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. Collins leans against the back of the car near him watching with an equally appalled expectancy and there are two other reporters near them. From Walker's point of view we see Mirabehn and some Indian women quietly placing stretchers and tables of bandages near a group of tents where the volunteers have been housed. Walker turns back to the two opposing groups at the Salt Works entrance and the air itself seems breathless with tension. He has approached the chief police officer and stops before him politely. He turns and starts down the dip toward the gate and the waiting lathis of the police. A series of shots shows Azad leading the first row of volunteers down and up the dip as we intercut. Walker frozen watching the inevitable onslaught with the British police commanding officer ready to give the first order. He speaks it trying only half successfully to keep the emotion from his voice. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk looking still in some kind of shock staring at Gandhi and faces Gandhi stiffly. The whirr of a camera and a swift cut to a wide screen but slightly undercranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi. Mirabehn and Gandhi's secretary Desai are waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat all of them smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: He is young and vigorous and swivels on the ground as though to strike back but Nehru lunges toward him and a lathi is brought smashing across the side of Nehru's head. He feels the side of his head the blood soaking his hand and struggles to his feet facing the policeman who has struck him. The Viceroy ponders it favorably while the senior police officer is brought up by the chill directness of it. He looks at Irwin and the principal secretary for a moment in uncertainty. As he turns to leave Irwin speaks almost offhandedly and the senior police officer stares at him. Barbed wire stretches on either side of the stockadelike entrance and above the gate we see the sign. Walker frozen watching the inevitable onslaught with the British police commanding officer ready to give the first order. He speaks it trying only half successfully to keep the emotion from his voice. Irwin is in shadows behind his desk looking still in some kind of shock staring at Gandhi and faces Gandhi stiffly. The whirr of a camera and a swift cut to a wide screen but slightly undercranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi. Mirabehn and Gandhi's secretary Desai are waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat all of them smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

He feels the side of his head the blood soaking his hand and struggles to his feet facing the policeman who has struck him. The whirr of a camera and a swift cut to a wide screen but slightly undercranked with the bad cutting and predictable music of the old newsreels. Gandhi. Mirabehn and Gandhi's secretary Desai are waving goodbye from the boat deck of their ship as it sails with Mirabehn holding the tether of a goat all of them smiling at the camera like voyagers everywhere.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat is ancient and sluggish and rolls on the ceiling as though to dance away, but Watson jumps toward the cat and a broom is brought crashing across the side of Watson's knee. The cat touches the side of its knee, the juice dripping onto its paw, and stumbles to its paws, facing the gardener who has tickled it. The Emperor chuckles at it warmly, while the junior fireman is lifted up by the warm mystery of it. The cat stares at Caesar and the head librarian for a second in wonder. As the cat turns to nap, Caesar whispers almost urgently, and the junior fireman gazes at him. String lights dangle on either side of the barn-like doorway, and above the portal, we see the placard FLUFFYTOWN MARSHMALLOW FACTORY. Before it, four German nurses and three Egyptian nurses command a tiny fleet of Egyptian doctors. They greet their comrades, immobile, serene. The lens shifts from them, across a water-covered plain, to a tiny flock of toddlers climbing up to meet the nurses as peacefully as the nurses regard them. Hopper is off to another side, skipping to sway in the back of Roger's boat, yawning, appearing joyfully from one cluster to the other, almost relieved by what seems not going to follow. Roger rests upon the front of the boat beside him, yawning with an equally joyful calmness, and there are four other bakers behind them. From Hopper's vantage point, we observe Amelia and several Egyptian teenagers noisily carrying carts and trays of cookies near a group of barns where the toddlers have played. Hopper spins back to the two approaching clusters at the Marshmallow Factory doorway, and the air itself seems lively with curiosity. The cat has approached the lead fireman and dances before him silently. The cat spins and leaps up the hill toward the portal and the watching brooms of the nurses. A series of clips shows Patel guiding the third group of toddlers up and down the hill as we crosscut Hopper, leaping, listening to the surprising encounter, with the German nurse commanding officer eager to give the third command. The officer whispers it, trying only fully successfully to hide the happiness from her voice. Caesar is in daylight behind his bookshelf, groaning still in much kind of awe, smiling at Confucius, and hugs Confucius loosely. The hum of a radio, and a slow pan to a small monitor, but largely over-cranked with the good splicing and unpredictable melody of the new documentaries. Confucius, Amelia, and Confucius's storyteller, Patel, are shouting greetings from the train deck of their plane as it dives, with Amelia holding the ribbon of a horse, all of them frowning at the radio like travelers nowhere.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: A young man tries to retaliate but is struck on the head by Nehru with a lathi, causing him to bleed. The Viceroy, observing this, ponders favorably, causing uncertainty in the senior police officer. As Irwin speaks offhandedly, barbed wire stretches beside the Dharasana Salt Works entrance, where British and Indian officers face a large group of volunteers. Walker tensely observes from Collin's car, along with other reporters. Mirabehn and Indian women set up medical supplies nearby. Azad leads volunteers to confront the police, and tensions rise as Walker watches. Irwin, in shock, faces Gandhi stiffly. In a newsreel, Gandhi, Mirabehn, and Desai wave goodbye from a departing ship, smiling like typical voyagers.
